Consolidation of sentencing legislation: amendment of law for old offences
	In this section—
		  * “repealed provision” means— 
		an enactment, to the extent that it is to be repealed or revoked by thesentencing consolidation;
		a provision made under such an enactment;
			  * “transition time”, in relation to a repealed provision, means a time that is specified in, or determined in accordance with, an enactment relating to the coming into force of the repealed provision or any other enactment; 
			  * “trigger event”, in relation to an offence, means the commission of the offence or any event related to the commission of the offence, including any event— 
		connected with, or which constitutes any part of, the commission of theoffence, or
		related to the investigation of, or proceedings related to, the offence.
	Subsection (3) applies if a person is convicted of an offence on or afterthe consolidation date.
	Where— 
		the application to the offence of a repealed provision depends on the timeat which a particular trigger event occurred in relation to a particulartransition time, and
		the transition time fell after the trigger event occurred,
			the repealed provision has effect as if the transition time had instead fallenbefore the trigger event occurred.
	Subsection (3) does not operate so far as it would increase—
		the maximum term of imprisonment or detention, or
		the maximum fine,
		with which the offence is punishable.
	Subsection (3) is also subject to—
		Schedule 1 (exceptions);
		any provision made by regulations made by the Secretary of State for thepurpose of securing that subsection (3) does not affect the application ofparticular repealed provisions.
	Where a repealed provision has effect in accordance with subsection (3),any related enactment also has effect in accordance with that subsection.
	The following have effect subject to subsections (3) to (6)—
		a commencement or transitional provision relating to the coming into forceof a repealed provision or any related enactment;
		a saving subject to which a repealed provision, or any related enactment,has previously been repealed or revoked.
	For the purposes of this section—
		“related enactment”, in relation to a repealed provision, means anenactment which—
		came into force subject to the same commencement or transitional provisionas the repealed provision, or
		has previously been repealed or revoked subject to the same saving as therepealed provision,
		so far as it is necessary for the repealed provision to have full effect;
		“repealed provision” and “related enactment” do not include a provision tothe extent that it is not in force immediately before the consolidation date,except to the extent that it will come into force on or after that date byvirtue of an enactment passed or made before that date;
		a reference to the application of a repealed provision includes a referenceto whether or not it applies (or applies for a particular purpose), and to theform in which it applies (or applies for a particular purpose);
		references to a repealed provision or related enactment or to anycommencement or transitional provision or saving include references to such aprovision passed or made after the passing of this Act.
Pre-consolidation amendments relating to sentencing
	Schedule 2 contains amendments and modifications of sentencing legislationwhich are designed to facilitate, or otherwise desirable in connection with,the consolidation of the whole or a substantial part of the Acts relating tosentencing (with or without other sentencing legislation).
	The Secretary of State may by regulations make such further amendments andmodifications of sentencing legislation (including Schedule 2) as in theSecretary of State’s opinion facilitate, or are otherwise desirable inconnection with, the consolidation of the whole or a substantial part of theActs relating to sentencing (with or without other sentencing legislation).
	In exercising the power under this section, the Secretary of State may haveregard in particular to the desirability of removing differences betweenprovisions relating to—
		forfeiture; 
		powers of different courts to deal with offenders subject to particularsentences;
		powers of different courts to provide for when sentences or particularrequirements of sentences are to take effect.
	Provision that may be made by regulations under this section includes, inparticular, provision amending or modifying any provision of sentencinglegislation which—
		confers power to make legislation, and
		is subject to a relevant restriction,
			so as to amend or modify that restriction.
		A “relevant restriction” is one by virtue of which legislation made inexercise of the power is to come into force only for cases in which commissionor conviction of an offence, or any other event, occurs after the time whenthe legislation is made or comes into force, or any other particular time.
	For the purposes of this section, “amend” includes repeal or revoke (andsimilar terms are to be read accordingly).
Interpretation 
	In this Act—
		  * “the Acts relating to sentencing” means— 
		the Powers of Criminal Courts (Sentencing) Act 2000;
		Part 12 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003;
		the following Acts so far as relating to the sentencing of offenders inEngland and Wales—
		the Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005;
		the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008;
		the Coroners and Justice Act 2009;
		the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012;
		the Offender Rehabilitation Act 2014;
		the Criminal Justice and Courts Act 2015,
			and any other provision of an Act so far as it relates to the sentencing ofoffenders in England and Wales, whenever passed;
			  * “the consolidation date” means the date on which the sentencing consolidation is to come into force (except so far as it consolidates legislation that is not in force immediately before that date); 
			  * “enactment” includes an enactment contained in subordinate legislation; 
			  * “the sentencing consolidation” means, if an Act or group of Acts of a kind mentioned in section 5(2) is passed, that Act or group of Acts; 
			  * “sentencing legislation” means any enactment, whenever passed or made which is— 
		an enactment relating to the sentencing of offenders, including any power tomake such an enactment, or
		an enactment referring to, or applying, modifying, amending, repealing orrevoking, an enactment within paragraph (a);
			  * “the sentencing of offenders” includes anything done by a court, including making an order— 
		in relation to a parent or guardian of an offender, or
		relating to the behaviour of the offender,
		when dealing with an offender for an offence.
	References in this Act to a person’s being convicted include—
		a special verdict (within the meaning of section 1 of the CriminalProcedure (Insanity) Act 1964) being returned,
		a finding mentioned in section 5(1)(b) of that Act being made of theperson’s having done the act or made the omission charged (following a findingof being under a disability), and
		being convicted by or before a service court (within the meaning given insection 305 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003).
Regulations 
	Any power to make regulations under section 1 or 2 is exercisable bystatutory instrument.
	A statutory instrument containing any such regulations may not be madeunless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and approved by aresolution of each House of Parliament.
	Any such regulations are to come into force in accordance with section 5.
Commencement, extent and short title
	So far as necessary to enable regulations to be made under section 1 or 2,this Act comes into force on the day on which it is passed.
	Subject to that, this Act, and any regulations made under section 1 or 2,do not come into force unless—
		a single Act, or
		a group of two or more Acts,
			is passed consolidating the whole or a substantial part of the Acts relatingto sentencing (with or without other sentencing legislation).
	If the sentencing consolidation is passed, this Act, so far as not alreadyin force, and any regulations made under section 1 or 2—
		come into force immediately before the consolidation date, and
		so far as they apply in relation to an offence, have effect only inrelation to an offence of which a person is convicted on or after that date.
	Subject to the following, this Act extends to England and Wales only.
	A modification of a provision by section 1 has the same extent within theUnited Kingdom as the provision modified.
	An amendment, repeal or revocation made by Schedule 2, or by regulationsunder section 2, has the same extent within the United Kingdom as theprovision amended, repealed or revoked.
	In Schedule 2—
		paragraph 133 also extends to Northern Ireland, and
		paragraph 134 also extends to Scotland and Northern Ireland.
	The power conferred by section 338 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (powerto extend to Channel Islands and Isle of Man, and to modify) is exercisable inrelation to any amendment or modification of that Act that is made by or underthis Act.
	The armed forces provisions also extend to—
		the Isle of Man, and
		the British overseas territories except Gibraltar.
	The powers conferred by section 384 of the Armed Forces Act 2006 (power toextend Act to the Channel Islands and powers to make provisions of that Actapply with modifications in relation to the Channel Islands, British overseasterritories and the Isle of Man) are exercisable in relation to any armedforces provision.
	“Armed forces provision” means—
		an amendment, modification or repeal made by or under this Act of aprovision of the Armed Forces Act 2006;
		an amendment, modification or repeal made by or under this Act of any otherprovision, so far as the provision is applied (by whatever words) by or underthe Armed Forces Act 2006.
	This Act may be cited as the Sentencing (Pre-consolidation Amendments) Act2020.
